intro: Gynoxys ferreyrae, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its vibrant orange-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, thriving in well-drained soils and full sunlight. Its leaves are usually alternate, simple, and covered in fine hairs, while its stem is erect and somewhat woody. Gynoxys ferreyrae is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.
